You have to specify the host name of your ec2 instance in the argument of this step: https://zulip.readthedocs.io/en/latest/production/install.html#step-2-install-zulip.
./zulip-server-*/scripts/setup/install --certbot \ --email=YOUR_EMAIL --hostname=YOUR_HOSTNAME (the hostname).
Hostname as in the public url of the ec2 instance.

You posted in the wrong topic. I have moved your messages to the correct topic.
You don't have to set the domain name. It is set by Amazon. However, the name changes whenever you reboot, so it's not good to use that.

Okay
Go to something like https://us-east-2.console.aws.amazon.com/ec2/v2/home?region=us-east-2#Instances:. And click on your instance to get its details.
Of course it depends on the ec2 region you picked.
As long as you don't restart the Ubuntu instance, you can use the name given by Amazon, if you just want to run a test Zulip instance.

Rein Zustand said:

You don't have to set the domain name. It is set by Amazon. However, the name changes whenever you reboot, so it's not good to use that.

where it is set by Amazon..How can I provide that into /etc/hosts..Please help

OK, let's back up.

AWS will provide you with a random host with a random hostname. If you stop and start your server (which you may be forced to do if it has hardware problems), you may get a different host and thus a different hostname.

To use your server, you're going to need to give it another name other than the one that AWS has for it. That's generally done by buying a domain name (like example.com), and registering a host in that domain (like zulip.example.com) which points to the same server. By "points to" most folks use what's called a CNAME record, which is how DNS says "this name (zulip.example.com) is an alias for ec2-65-0-011-123.ap-south-1.compute.amazonaws.com)" and browsers will know to find who zulip.example.com is based on that.

When you set up Zulip, you should use the friendly name you made (zulip.example.com). This is because that's what users will be typing into their browsers, and that's how SSL will know they have the right host (this is a simplification). In the case that you need to turn your host off and back on again, and AWS gives you a different computer, you can change the CNAME to point to the new host they gave you -- and your users will be none the wiser, since they will continue to use zulip.example.com

If you click on the instance in the EC2 instances list, there's a part in the top of the resulting page that says "Public IPv4 DNS". You can try using that name, but I don't know if AWS has configured things to let you actually get that certificate.

My suggestion is to set it up correctly from the start. Get the domain name, set it up in in Route53.

Alex Vandiver said:

If you click on the instance in the EC2 instances list, there's a part in the top of the resulting page that says "Public IPv4 DNS". You can try using that name, but I don't know if AWS has configured things to let you actually get that certificate.

My suggestion is to set it up correctly from the start. Get the domain name, set it up in in Route53.

My suggestion is to set it up correctly from the start. Get the domain name, set it up in in Route53.

Could you please share me step by step reference to install on Aws .

I don't have a more specific guide to point you at, other than the instructions above, and our general installation guide.

Again, my recommendation is to buy the domain name, CNAME zulip.whatever.com to the host (if you use Route53, AWS even has an "alias" which is even better, since it will get updated if the underlying host moves), and then do your setup on the machine using that name.

@Md Nishad Hussain The steps are described in the relevant section in /etc/zulip/settings.py:

################
## Outgoing email (SMTP) settings.
##
## Zulip needs to be able to send email (that is, use SMTP) so it can
## confirm new users' email addresses and send notifications.
##
## If you don't already have an SMTP provider, free ones are available.
##
## For more details, including a list of free SMTP providers and
## advice for troubleshooting, see the Zulip documentation:
##   https://zulip.readthedocs.io/en/latest/production/email.html

## EMAIL_HOST and EMAIL_HOST_USER are generally required.
# EMAIL_HOST = 'smtp.example.com'
# EMAIL_HOST_USER = ''

## Passwords and secrets are not stored in this file.  The password
## for user EMAIL_HOST_USER goes in `/etc/zulip/zulip-secrets.conf`.
## In that file, set `email_password`.  For example:
# email_password = abcd1234

## EMAIL_USE_TLS and EMAIL_PORT are required for most SMTP providers.
# EMAIL_USE_TLS = True
# EMAIL_PORT = 587

And if that's configured, you can just run something like manage.py send_test_email some_address@example.com to test if it actually works - the output may be useful for figuring out what's wrong if there are issues

Are you sure that you do not set the mail adress as administrator mail adress?
Zulip does try to send some mails from that one

You probably want to read https://zulip.readthedocs.io/en/latest/production/email.html if you haven't already. IIRC by default it wants to send from one fixed address and one domain, but I think if need be you can use a fixed address for the second thing too.

It's not going to try to send from the address of every user that signs up, so it's not an unbounded problem to authorize each sender. (There's just the two things, not "every possible address on the internet".)

Alex Dehnert said:

You probably want to read https://zulip.readthedocs.io/en/latest/production/email.html if you haven't already. IIRC by default it wants to send from one fixed address and one domain, but I think if need be you can use a fixed address for the second thing too.

It's not going to try to send from the address of every user that signs up, so it's not an unbounded problem to authorize each sender. (There's just the two things, not "every possible address on the internet".)

Hi, i think your SES is misconfigured and not production ready... I only read across the text (in the given link). Maybe this point is important:

  • Check whether your account is in the Amazon SES sandbox for the AWS Region that you're using to send emails. If your account is in the Amazon SES sandbox, then you must verify the recipient email address, in addition to verifying your sender identity. Or, you can request to move your account out of the Amazon SES sandbox.
    Note: If you're using sending authorization policies to delegate sending on behalf of your Amazon SES identity to a non-verified email address, the delegate sender account must be out of the Amazon SES sandbox. For more information, see Moving out of the Amazon SES sandbox.

Your error messages above come all from AWS SES side (message rejected, ...), not from your zulip instance...

    Note: If you're using sending authorization policies to delegate sending on behalf of your Amazon SES identity to a non-verified email address, the delegate sender account must be out of the Amazon SES sandbox. For more information, see Moving out of the Amazon SES sandbox.

1. Confirm that the identity you're sending emails from has a verification status of verified, not pending or failure?
  2. If your email address is verified, check that the email address on the message that resulted in the "Message rejected" error is correct. Email addresses are case-sensitive. The email address that you used to send the message must match your verified email address exactly?
  3. Check whether your account is in the Amazon SES sandbox for the AWS Region that you're using to send emails?
  4. Confirm that your email-sending method is using the correct AWS Region?
  5. Confirm that you're connecting to the correct Amazon SES endpoint?

So all points are really fulfilled, like it is mentioned in the link?

Ronny said:

  1. Confirm that the identity you're sending emails from has a verification status of verified, not pending or failure?
  2. If your email address is verified, check that the email address on the message that resulted in the "Message rejected" error is correct. Email addresses are case-sensitive. The email address that you used to send the message must match your verified email address exactly?
  3. Check whether your account is in the Amazon SES sandbox for the AWS Region that you're using to send emails?
  4. Confirm that your email-sending method is using the correct AWS Region?
  5. Confirm that you're connecting to the correct Amazon SES endpoint?

Hi All,

Can anyone explain what is the difference between Zulip Cloud and Self host Zulip app on AWS EC2 Server?

  1. what are the pros and cons.
  2. Advantages and Disadvantages
  3. when to use and why?

Most importantly, which one is the best use for an organisation?

@Md Nishad Hussain one is not better than the other; different options make sense for different organizations. For example, self-hosting Zulip lets you retain full control of your data and customize Zulip as needed. Zulip Cloud lets you create a Zulip organization with just a few clicks, rather than having to set up a server, so it's the simpler option. It will also be automatically upgraded to the latest version of Zulip, so you always get the newest features.

As @Felix (strifel) said, this community can help answer some questions... However, if you need extensive support with your Zulip setup, please contact support@zulip.com, and we can discuss setting up a paid Zulip support contract for you.
